<ce:section-title>Graphical abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0005" view="all">Using the flexible ligand oxydiacetic acid (H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>oda), nine heterodimetallic polymers [{Ca(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>}{CaLn(oda)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>}<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (Ln<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Y, Eu, Tb, Dy, Ho, Er, Tm, Yb, Lu) were synthesized and structurally characterized. They are isostructural and possess a highly ordered structure with [CaLn(oda)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> as building blocks. The charge is balanced with [Ca(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> ions which occupy the holes of the anionic framework. Magnetic susceptibility measurements of Yb and Eu complexes show deviations from the Curie law mainly owing to the split of the ground term due to the ligand field and to the depopulating of paramagnetic excited states in the Yb and Eu compounds, respectively.<ce:display>

</ce:figure>
</ce:display>

elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract
Using the flexible ligand oxydiacetic acid (H2oda), nine heterodimetallic polymers [{Ca(H2O)6}{CaLn(oda)3}2]·xH2O (Ln=Y, Eu, Tb, Dy, Ho, Er, Tm, Yb, Lu) were synthesized and structurally characterized. They are isostructural and possess a highly ordered structure with [CaLn(oda)3]− as building blocks. The charge is balanced with [Ca(H2O)6]2+ ions which occupy the holes of the anionic framework. Magnetic susceptibility measurements of Yb and Eu complexes show deviations from the Curie law mainly owing to the split of the ground term due to the ligand field and to the depopulating of paramagnetic excited states in the Yb and Eu compounds, respectively.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0015" view="all">Using the flexible ligand oxydiacetic acid (H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>oda), nine heterodimetallic polymers [{Ca(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>}{CaLn(oda)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>}<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (Ln<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Y, Eu, Tb, Dy, Ho, Er, Tm, Yb, Lu) were synthesized and structurally characterized. The syntheses were performed in aqueous solution by reaction of the ligand and salts of the two ions. They are isostructural and possess a highly ordered 3D structure with [CaLn(oda)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> as building blocks. The charge is balanced with [Ca(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> ions which occupy the holes of the anionic framework. The complexes are thermally stable up to 250<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. Magnetic susceptibility measurements of Yb and Eu complexes show deviations from the Curie law mainly owing to the split of the ground term due to the ligand field and to the depopulating of paramagnetic excited states in the Yb and Eu compounds, respectively.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract
Using the flexible ligand oxydiacetic acid (H2oda), nine heterodimetallic polymers [{Ca(H2O)6}{CaLn(oda)3}2]·xH2O (Ln=Y, Eu, Tb, Dy, Ho, Er, Tm, Yb, Lu) were synthesized and structurally characterized. The syntheses were performed in aqueous solution by reaction of the ligand and salts of the two ions. They are isostructural and possess a highly ordered 3D structure with [CaLn(oda)3]− as building blocks. The charge is balanced with [Ca(H2O)6]2+ ions which occupy the holes of the anionic framework. The complexes are thermally stable up to 250°C. Magnetic susceptibility measurements of Yb and Eu complexes show deviations from the Curie law mainly owing to the split of the ground term due to the ligand field and to the depopulating of paramagnetic excited states in the Yb and Eu compounds, respectively.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0005" view="all">The rapid development of material science and chemistry has directed the attention of an increasing number of scientists to search for new crystal materials. In particular, the design and synthesis of open-framework coordination polymers made from metal ions connected by bridging organic ligands have been of great interest in view of their intriguing variety of architectures, topologies and applications . Very remarkable differences from purely inorganic solids (such as zeolites) are the larger pore volume and the ability to display structural response to adsorption of small molecules through the organic functional groups .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction
The rapid development of material science and chemistry has directed the attention of an increasing number of scientists to search for new crystal materials. In particular, the design and synthesis of open-framework coordination polymers made from metal ions connected by bridging organic ligands have been of great interest in view of their intriguing variety of architectures, topologies and applications . Very remarkable differences from purely inorganic solids (such as zeolites) are the larger pore volume and the ability to display structural response to adsorption of small molecules through the organic functional groups .

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0010" view="all">In this context, 3d–4f heterometallic coordination polymers present additional and interesting features. They allow the study of the magnetic interactions between the spin carriers through the chemical bridges, and new luminescent porous materials can be prepared, using the sharp fluorescent emissions of the lanthanide ions .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In this context, 3d–4f heterometallic coordination polymers present additional and interesting features. They allow the study of the magnetic interactions between the spin carriers through the chemical bridges, and new luminescent porous materials can be prepared, using the sharp fluorescent emissions of the lanthanide ions .

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0015" view="all">Polycarboxylic acids are extensively used as linkers in the construction of these materials. They provide the dimensionality of the network and tune (together with the coordination number of the metal ion) the pore size and shape. The flexible ligand 2,2′-oxydiacetic acid (H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>oda) has been successfully used to prepare heteropolymetallic coordination compounds with general formula [Ln<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>M<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(oda)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>] (M<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>bivalent cation) (reviewed in ). The first report on these compounds contained the crystal structure of [Gd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Cu<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(oda)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]·3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O . Later, the series was extended with the analogous compounds with La, Ce, Pr, Nd, Sm, Eu, Tb, Dy, Ho, Y, Er, Yb, and finally, a few of non-containing copper(II) complex, [La<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Co<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(oda)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]·12H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O , [Sm<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Zn<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(oda)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]·1.5H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O , [La<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Zn<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(oda)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O , and [Ce<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Zn<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(oda)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]·1.5H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O  were prepared. The synthesis is straightforward by a direct combination of the reactants in aqueous solution. The complexes are isostructural (hexagonal crystal system, <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>6/<ce:italic>mcc</ce:italic> space group) and contain nine-coordinated Ln ions surrounded by nine O atoms from three independent oda ligands. The building block [Ln(oda)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>] still has uncoordinated O-carboxylate donor atoms which are able to link [M(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] (M<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Cu, Co, Zn) units. The structure contains large hexagonal channels (average diameter 10.7<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) along the crystallographic <ce:italic>c</ce:italic> axis which houses the crystallization water molecules. The magnetic properties of the complexes were investigated, showing weak antiferromagnetic interactions M(II)–M(II) in the low temperature range .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Polycarboxylic acids are extensively used as linkers in the construction of these materials. They provide the dimensionality of the network and tune (together with the coordination number of the metal ion) the pore size and shape. The flexible ligand 2,2′-oxydiacetic acid (H2oda) has been successfully used to prepare heteropolymetallic coordination compounds with general formula [Ln2M3(oda)6] (M=bivalent cation) (reviewed in ). The first report on these compounds contained the crystal structure of [Gd2Cu3(oda)6(H2O)6]·3H2O . Later, the series was extended with the analogous compounds with La, Ce, Pr, Nd, Sm, Eu, Tb, Dy, Ho, Y, Er, Yb, and finally, a few of non-containing copper(II) complex, [La2Co3(oda)6(H2O)6]·12H2O , [Sm2Zn3(oda)6(H2O)6]·1.5H2O , [La2Zn3(oda)6(H2O)6]·6H2O , and [Ce2Zn3(oda)6(H2O)6]·1.5H2O  were prepared. The synthesis is straightforward by a direct combination of the reactants in aqueous solution. The complexes are isostructural (hexagonal crystal system, P6/mcc space group) and contain nine-coordinated Ln ions surrounded by nine O atoms from three independent oda ligands. The building block [Ln(oda)3] still has uncoordinated O-carboxylate donor atoms which are able to link [M(H2O)2] (M=Cu, Co, Zn) units. The structure contains large hexagonal channels (average diameter 10.7Å) along the crystallographic c axis which houses the crystallization water molecules. The magnetic properties of the complexes were investigated, showing weak antiferromagnetic interactions M(II)–M(II) in the low temperature range .

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0020" view="all">More recently, the complex [Mn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Gd<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(oda)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]·12H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O was prepared and fully characterized . It was synthesized by a similar procedure and follows the general formulae of the previous polynuclear complexes. However, the crystal structure (cubic crystal system, <mml:math altimg="si1.gif" overflow="scroll">

<mml:mi mathvariant="italic">Fd</mml:mi>

The [Gd(oda)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>] building blocks are still present but the Mn(II) ions are not equivalent. One of them links the building blocks and forms a 3D structure with cubic cavities, some filled by water molecules and others occupied by [Mn(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> cations. This spatial arrangement provokes a ferromagnetic interaction between the Gd(III)–Mn(II) ions, which is responsible for the magnetic behavior in the low-temperature range.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
More recently, the complex [Mn2Gd3(oda)6]·12H2O was prepared and fully characterized . It was synthesized by a similar procedure and follows the general formulae of the previous polynuclear complexes. However, the crystal structure (cubic crystal system, 

Fd


3


¯


c

 space group) is completely different and should be better described as [{Mn(H2O)6}{MnGd(oda)3}2]·6H2O. The [Gd(oda)3] building blocks are still present but the Mn(II) ions are not equivalent. One of them links the building blocks and forms a 3D structure with cubic cavities, some filled by water molecules and others occupied by [Mn(H2O)6]2+ cations. This spatial arrangement provokes a ferromagnetic interaction between the Gd(III)–Mn(II) ions, which is responsible for the magnetic behavior in the low-temperature range.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0025" view="all">The change of structure (hexagonal to cubic) in the [Ln<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>M<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(oda)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]·<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O complexes also produces materials with different H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> uptake after removing the crystallization water molecules. For example, [Sm<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Zn<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(oda)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]·1.5H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (hexagonal) exhibits 1.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>wt% of H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> uptake at 77<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K, while [Sm<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Co<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(oda)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]·3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (cubic) does not show hydrogen uptake .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The change of structure (hexagonal to cubic) in the [Ln2M3(oda)6(H2O)6]·xH2O complexes also produces materials with different H2 uptake after removing the crystallization water molecules. For example, [Sm2Zn3(oda)6(H2O)6]·1.5H2O (hexagonal) exhibits 1.2wt% of H2 uptake at 77K, while [Sm2Co3(oda)6(H2O)6]·3H2O (cubic) does not show hydrogen uptake .

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0030" view="all">The reasons for the difference in the structure of the complexes are not clear up to now. The symmetry of the M(II) cation could have influence on this change. Cu(II) ion with four short equatorial positions and two elongated ones (Jahn–Teller effect) would force an hexagonal structure. On the other hand, the spherical Mn(II) seems to be symmetrically adapted for a cubic structure. The size of the [M(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> cation compared to the cavity free space could also play an important role in determining the structure of the polynuclear complex.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The reasons for the difference in the structure of the complexes are not clear up to now. The symmetry of the M(II) cation could have influence on this change. Cu(II) ion with four short equatorial positions and two elongated ones (Jahn–Teller effect) would force an hexagonal structure. On the other hand, the spherical Mn(II) seems to be symmetrically adapted for a cubic structure. The size of the [M(H2O)6]2+ cation compared to the cavity free space could also play an important role in determining the structure of the polynuclear complex.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0035" view="all">With this mind, we have started a systematic study of the solid-state structure of [Ln<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>M<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(oda)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]·<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O complexes. In this work we prepared and characterized nine novel and isostructural complexes with Ca(II) and different Ln ions: Y, Eu, Tb, Dy, Ho, Er, Tm, Yb, Lu. Yttrium was also included in this group due to the well-known similarities with the lanthanide elements, in spite of being an element of the group 3. In addition, the magnetic properties of two of them were measured.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: With this mind, we have started a systematic study of the solid-state structure of [Ln2M3(oda)6(H2O)6]·xH2O complexes. In this work we prepared and characterized nine novel and isostructural complexes with Ca(II) and different Ln ions: Y, Eu, Tb, Dy, Ho, Er, Tm, Yb, Lu. Yttrium was also included in this group due to the well-known similarities with the lanthanide elements, in spite of being an element of the group 3. In addition, the magnetic properties of two of them were measured.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Experimental</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>Materials and methods</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0040" view="all">All common laboratory chemicals were reagent grade, purchased from commercial sources and used without further purification. LnCl<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (Ln<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Y, Eu, Tb, Ho, Er, Yb), Ln<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (Ln<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Dy, Tm, Lu), and CaCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O were used as metal sources. 2,2-Oxydiacetic acid was purchased from Fluka.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Experimental
Materials and methods
All common laboratory chemicals were reagent grade, purchased from commercial sources and used without further purification. LnCl3·6H2O (Ln=Y, Eu, Tb, Ho, Er, Yb), Ln2O3 (Ln=Dy, Tm, Lu), and CaCl2·2H2O were used as metal sources. 2,2-Oxydiacetic acid was purchased from Fluka.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0045" view="all">The infrared spectra, as KBr pellets, were obtained from a Bomen MB 102 FT-IR spectrophotometer. Elemental analysis (C, H) was performed on a Flash 2000 instrument. Thermal analysis was performed on a Shimadzu TGA-50 instrument with a TA 50I interface, using a platinum cell and nitrogen atmosphere. Experimental conditions were 0.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>min<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> temperature ramp rate and 50<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>min<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> nitrogen flow rate.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The infrared spectra, as KBr pellets, were obtained from a Bomen MB 102 FT-IR spectrophotometer. Elemental analysis (C, H) was performed on a Flash 2000 instrument. Thermal analysis was performed on a Shimadzu TGA-50 instrument with a TA 50I interface, using a platinum cell and nitrogen atmosphere. Experimental conditions were 0.5°Cmin−1 temperature ramp rate and 50mLmin−1 nitrogen flow rate.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0050" view="all">Magnetic susceptibility measurements were carried out on polycrystalline samples by means of a Quantum Design SQUID magnetometer. The dc measurements were performed in the temperature range 1.9–300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K at applied magnetic fields of 1000<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Oe for <ce:italic>T</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp><<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>15<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K and 10000<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Oe for <ce:italic>T</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>><ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K. Diamagnetic corrections of the constituent atoms were estimated from Pascal’s constants  and the magnetization of the sample holder.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic susceptibility measurements were carried out on polycrystalline samples by means of a Quantum Design SQUID magnetometer. The dc measurements were performed in the temperature range 1.9–300K at applied magnetic fields of 1000Oe for T
<15K and 10000Oe for T
>10K. Diamagnetic corrections of the constituent atoms were estimated from Pascal’s constants  and the magnetization of the sample holder.

elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of the complexes
Synthesis of [{Ca(H2O)6}{CaLn(oda)3}2]·4H2O
(Ln=Y (1), Eu (2), Tb (3), Ho (4), Er (5), Yb (6)). CaCl2·2H2O (0.11g, 0.75mmol) and LnCl3·6H2O (0.50mmol) were dissolved in 10mL of water. 2,2-Oxydiacetic acid (0.20g, 1.5mmol) were dissolved in another 10mL of water, and the pH value was adjusted to 7.0 with ammonium hydroxide. Both solutions were mixed, and a clear solution was obtained. The solution was allowed to evaporate slowly at room temperature. After some weeks, cubic crystals were obtained. Yield 30–50%. Anal. Calc. for C24H44O40Ca3Ln2: C, 22.7; H, 3.5 (1); C, 20.6; H, 3.2 (2); 20.4; H, 3.1 (3); 20.2; H, 3.1 (4); 20.2; H, 3.1 (5); 20.0; H, 3.1 (6). Found: C, 23.4; H, 3.2 (1); C, 20.4; H, 3.3 (2); 20.5; H, 3.1 (3); 19.7; H, 3.4 (4); 20.4; H, 3.4 (5); 21.2; H, 3.4 (6)%. TGA diagrams show a single weight loss between room temperature and 200°C, corresponding to all water molecules (Fig. S1). Anal. Calc.: 14.2 (1); 12.9 (2); 12.8 (3); 12.7 (4); 12.6 (5); 12.5 (6). Found: 13.9 (1); 13.0 (2); 11.9 (3); 12.5 (4); 12.2 (5); 12.3 (6)%. Decomposition point, ca. 250°C.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Synthesis of [{Ca(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>}{CaLn(oda)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>}<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0060" view="all">(Ln<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Dy (<ce:bold>7</ce:bold>), Tm (<ce:bold>8</ce:bold>), Lu (<ce:bold>9</ce:bold>). The mixture of Ln<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (0.10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) CaCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (44<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.30<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) and 2,2-oxydiacetic acid (80<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.60<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) in 15<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL of water was placed in a Teflon-lined 45<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL stainless steel acid digestion vessel and heated at 120<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>days. The resulting clear solution was allowed to evaporate at room temperature. After some weeks, cubic crystals were obtained. Yield 30–50%. <ce:italic>Anal.</ce:italic> Calc. for C<ce:inf loc="post">24</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">44</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">40</ce:inf>Ca<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>Ln<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>: C, 20.3; H, 3.1 (<ce:bold>7</ce:bold>); C, 20.1; H, 3.1 (<ce:bold>8</ce:bold>), C, 20.0; H, 3.1 (<ce:bold>9</ce:bold>). Found: C, 20.4; H, 3.3 (<ce:bold>7</ce:bold>); C, 20.3; H, 2.9 (<ce:bold>8</ce:bold>), C, 20.1; H, 2.9 (<ce:bold>9</ce:bold>)%. TGA diagrams show a single weight loss between room temperature and 200<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, corresponding to all water molecules. <ce:italic>Anal.</ce:italic> Calc.: 12.7 (<ce:bold>7</ce:bold>); 12.6 (<ce:bold>8</ce:bold>), 12.5 (<ce:bold>9</ce:bold>). Found: 13.3 (<ce:bold>7</ce:bold>); 12.4 (<ce:bold>8</ce:bold>), 11.7 (<ce:bold>9</ce:bold>)%. Decomposition point, <ce:italic>ca.</ce:italic> 250<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of [{Ca(H2O)6}{CaLn(oda)3}2]·4H2O
(Ln=Dy (7), Tm (8), Lu (9). The mixture of Ln2O3 (0.10mmol) CaCl2·2H2O (44mg, 0.30mmol) and 2,2-oxydiacetic acid (80mg, 0.60mmol) in 15mL of water was placed in a Teflon-lined 45mL stainless steel acid digestion vessel and heated at 120°C for 2days. The resulting clear solution was allowed to evaporate at room temperature. After some weeks, cubic crystals were obtained. Yield 30–50%. Anal. Calc. for C24H44O40Ca3Ln2: C, 20.3; H, 3.1 (7); C, 20.1; H, 3.1 (8), C, 20.0; H, 3.1 (9). Found: C, 20.4; H, 3.3 (7); C, 20.3; H, 2.9 (8), C, 20.1; H, 2.9 (9)%. TGA diagrams show a single weight loss between room temperature and 200°C, corresponding to all water molecules. Anal. Calc.: 12.7 (7); 12.6 (8), 12.5 (9). Found: 13.3 (7); 12.4 (8), 11.7 (9)%. Decomposition point, ca. 250°C.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>X-ray crystallography</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0065" view="all">The X-ray diffraction data for all structures was collected at 293(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K with an Agilent SuperNOVA diffractometer with micro-focus X-ray using Mo radiation (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.71073<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) for compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>5</ce:bold>, and <ce:bold>6</ce:bold>, and Cu radiation (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1.54058<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) for compounds <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>7</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>9</ce:bold>. <ce:small-caps>crysalispro</ce:small-caps>
 software was used to collect, index, scale and apply analytical absorption corrections based on faces of the crystals for all compounds except for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> where an empirical correction using spherical harmonics was used.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
X-ray crystallography
The X-ray diffraction data for all structures was collected at 293(2)K with an Agilent SuperNOVA diffractometer with micro-focus X-ray using Mo radiation (λ
=0.71073Å) for compounds 1–3, 5, and 6, and Cu radiation (λ
=1.54058Å) for compounds 4, 7–9. crysalispro
 software was used to collect, index, scale and apply analytical absorption corrections based on faces of the crystals for all compounds except for 2 where an empirical correction using spherical harmonics was used.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0070" view="all">The structure solutions were obtained by direct methods, using the <ce:small-caps>sir</ce:small-caps>2011  program and refined using the <ce:small-caps>shelxl</ce:small-caps>-97  program. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal parameters using full-matrix least-squares procedures on <ce:italic>F</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>. All hydrogen atoms were allowed to ride on their parent atoms with <ce:italic>U</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">iso</ce:inf>(H)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>U</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">eq</ce:inf>(C) except for the water molecules that idealized positions were determined using the <ce:small-caps>olex</ce:small-caps>2 program . A factor of ½ in the occupancy was fixed for the crystallization water molecules.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
The structure solutions were obtained by direct methods, using the sir2011  program and refined using the shelxl-97  program. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal parameters using full-matrix least-squares procedures on F
2. All hydrogen atoms were allowed to ride on their parent atoms with U
iso(H)=1.2
U
eq(C) except for the water molecules that idealized positions were determined using the olex2 program . A factor of ½ in the occupancy was fixed for the crystallization water molecules.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0085" view="all">The same product can be obtained by hydrothermal synthesis starting from Ln<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> instead of LnCl<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>. For complexes <ce:bold>7</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>9</ce:bold>, this route was the best way to get single crystals. In all cases, the composition was supported by the elemental analysis and TGA determinations. Thermal analyses showed mass loss even at low temperatures as 50<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, suggesting the presence of weakly bonded water molecules (Fig. S1). The most important weight loss is detected at around 200<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, followed by decomposition at <ce:italic>ca</ce:italic>. 250<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The same product can be obtained by hydrothermal synthesis starting from Ln2O3 instead of LnCl3. For complexes 7–9, this route was the best way to get single crystals. In all cases, the composition was supported by the elemental analysis and TGA determinations. Thermal analyses showed mass loss even at low temperatures as 50°C, suggesting the presence of weakly bonded water molecules (Fig. S1). The most important weight loss is detected at around 200°C, followed by decomposition at ca. 250°C.

<ce:para id="p0100" view="all">Complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is taken as example to present and describe the structure in detail. The most relevant bond distances and angles are presented in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="t0010"></ce:float-anchor>. The structure contains an anionic network, [Ca(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> cations to balance the charge, and three crystallization water molecules. The number of crystallization water molecules found in the measured single crystal is not coincident with that determined in the bulk solid (see Section ). The presence of very weakly bound water molecules (as reflected in the TGA profiles) would account for this fact.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Complex 2 is taken as example to present and describe the structure in detail. The most relevant bond distances and angles are presented in 
. The structure contains an anionic network, [Ca(H2O)6]2+ cations to balance the charge, and three crystallization water molecules. The number of crystallization water molecules found in the measured single crystal is not coincident with that determined in the bulk solid (see Section ). The presence of very weakly bound water molecules (as reflected in the TGA profiles) would account for this fact.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0105" view="all">Europium(III) ion is nine-coordinated, being surrounded by O atoms from three independent oda ligands. [Eu(oda)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> building blocks are clearly distinguished in the structure (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0010"></ce:float-anchor>). The Eu–O distances (2.406(4)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å for the alkoxo group and 2.469(5)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å for the carboxylate groups) are similar to those found in the simple salts of the complex [Eu(oda)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> (2.395(2) and 2.495(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, respectively) . The angles subtended by the coordinated oda oxygens at the europium atom in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are 63.96(9)° and 73.03(10)°, again very close to those observed in the salts of [Eu(oda)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> (63.4(1)° and 74.3(1)°). Therefore, the formation of the 3D structure does not represent a further strain in the atomic disposition of the building block.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Europium(III) ion is nine-coordinated, being surrounded by O atoms from three independent oda ligands. [Eu(oda)3]3− building blocks are clearly distinguished in the structure (
). The Eu–O distances (2.406(4)Å for the alkoxo group and 2.469(5)Å for the carboxylate groups) are similar to those found in the simple salts of the complex [Eu(oda)3]3− (2.395(2) and 2.495(2)Å, respectively) . The angles subtended by the coordinated oda oxygens at the europium atom in 2 are 63.96(9)° and 73.03(10)°, again very close to those observed in the salts of [Eu(oda)3]3− (63.4(1)° and 74.3(1)°). Therefore, the formation of the 3D structure does not represent a further strain in the atomic disposition of the building block.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0110" view="all">Each [Eu(oda)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> unit is connected to six Ca atoms through the free (non-bonded to Eu) oxygen atoms in an <ce:italic>anti</ce:italic>–<ce:italic>anti</ce:italic> configuration, forming the anionic network [CaEu(oda)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0015"></ce:float-anchor>). Thus, each Ca(II) center is surrounded by six [Eu(oda)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>] units in an undistorted octahedral geometry. Cubic-like holes are formed in the anionic structure (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0020"></ce:float-anchor>). They are limited by alternating Ca1 and Eu atoms in the vertexes at 6.6767(1)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, and the oda ligands, almost planar, in the faces of the cubes. The [Ca(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> (which provides charge balance to the compound) and water molecules exist as guests in alternating holes of the 3D network (). This is a rare example in which isolated [Ca(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> units are found in metal–organic structures. Only three of such structures are found in the literature, [Ca(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>](azo)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (azo<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4′-hydroxyazobenzene-3-sulfonate) , [Ca(CN<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">10</ce:inf>][Ca(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>](CN<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
, and [Ca(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>] [HB(mt)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (B(mt)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>tris(3-methyl-2-thioimidazolyl)borate)) .</ce:para>

<ce:para id="p0115" view="all">It is interesting to discuss the inclusion of [Ca(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> in the holes of the anionic framework. There is an electrostatic interaction between the anionic network and the hexaaquocation which favors the inclusion. Hydrogen bonding also contribute to the interaction. The H atoms of the coordinated water molecules are at 2.37<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å of O2, and 2.53<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å of O3 in the cavity (Figs.  and S2). On the other hand, the hexaaquocation seems to have the appropriate size to fit in the hole of the anionic network. O–Ca–O distance is 4.654<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å (twice Ca2–O1w distance in ). Assuming the normal values for the water molecule H–O–H angle 105.5° and O–H distance 0.942<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å), we have a maximum distance of 5.80<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å between the extremes of the cation. This properly fits in the cube determined by the Ca1 and Eu atoms in the vertexes that are 6.68<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å apart (Fig. S2).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: It is interesting to discuss the inclusion of [Ca(H2O)6]2+ in the holes of the anionic framework. There is an electrostatic interaction between the anionic network and the hexaaquocation which favors the inclusion. Hydrogen bonding also contribute to the interaction. The H atoms of the coordinated water molecules are at 2.37Å of O2, and 2.53Å of O3 in the cavity (Figs.  and S2). On the other hand, the hexaaquocation seems to have the appropriate size to fit in the hole of the anionic network. O–Ca–O distance is 4.654Å (twice Ca2–O1w distance in ). Assuming the normal values for the water molecule H–O–H angle 105.5° and O–H distance 0.942Å), we have a maximum distance of 5.80Å between the extremes of the cation. This properly fits in the cube determined by the Ca1 and Eu atoms in the vertexes that are 6.68Å apart (Fig. S2).

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Magnetic properties</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0120" view="all">The magnetic properties of Ln(III) ions are very different from those of 3d ions. The 4f orbitals are shielded by the fully occupied 5s and 5p orbitals and these 4f<ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">n</ce:sup>
</ce:italic> electrons are almost not involved in the bonds between the lanthanide ion and its nearest neighbors. This makes the energy states of the 4f<ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">n</ce:sup>
</ce:italic> configurations to be, in a first approximation, those of the free ions. The influence of the environment is also much less pronounced than in the 3d ions (these are the arguments of the so called free-ion approximation) . On the other hand, the spin–orbit coupling has a much larger effect in the electronic properties than in the 3d ions. This has to be considered by applying the Russell–Sanders coupling scheme and once the effect of the spin orbit coupling has been considered, the influence of the ligand field and the magnetic interactions can be taken into account. In order to proceed to the analysis of the magnetic susceptibility data, first of all, the ground terms and the expected values for the χ<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">M</ce:inf>T</ce:italic> product at room temperature were calculated and then, the temperature dependence of the χ<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">M</ce:inf>T</ce:italic> product is interpreted. The behavior of Yb(III) and Eu(III) is very different and they will be studied separately.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic properties
The magnetic properties of Ln(III) ions are very different from those of 3d ions. The 4f orbitals are shielded by the fully occupied 5s and 5p orbitals and these 4f
n
 electrons are almost not involved in the bonds between the lanthanide ion and its nearest neighbors. This makes the energy states of the 4f
n
 configurations to be, in a first approximation, those of the free ions. The influence of the environment is also much less pronounced than in the 3d ions (these are the arguments of the so called free-ion approximation) . On the other hand, the spin–orbit coupling has a much larger effect in the electronic properties than in the 3d ions. This has to be considered by applying the Russell–Sanders coupling scheme and once the effect of the spin orbit coupling has been considered, the influence of the ligand field and the magnetic interactions can be taken into account. In order to proceed to the analysis of the magnetic susceptibility data, first of all, the ground terms and the expected values for the χ
MT product at room temperature were calculated and then, the temperature dependence of the χ
MT product is interpreted. The behavior of Yb(III) and Eu(III) is very different and they will be studied separately.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0140" view="all">The decrease of the values of the χ<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">M</ce:inf>T</ce:italic> product on lowering the temperature can be attributed to the occurrence of antiferromagnetic interactions between the Ln ions or to the loss of the degeneracy of the ground state by the crystal or ligand field. The ligand field breaks the degeneracy and splits the ground term into multiplets. If the width of the multiplets is small enough, the effect of the decrease of the temperature is then the depopulation of the components of higher energy which results in a deviation from the Curie law, having the same effect as antiferromagnetic interactions amongst the lanthanoid ions. Considering that the structure of the compound shows the Yb(III) ions very far from each other, the decrease of the χ<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">M</ce:inf>T</ce:italic> values on lowering the temperature are more likely due to the depopulation of the components of higher energy.</ce:para>

Considering that the structure of the compound shows the Yb(III) ions very far from each other, the decrease of the χ

elements.clean_text:
Concluding remarks
2,2′-Oxydiacetate has proved to bridge Ln(III) and different divalent cations. In this work, this interesting series has been expanded with the preparation of nine novel compounds [{Ca(H2O)6}{CaLn(oda)3}2]·4H2O (Ln=Y, Eu, Tb, Dy, Ho, Er, Tm, Yb, Lu). The compounds are rare metal-organic structures containing isolated [Ca(H2O)6]2+ units.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0160" view="all">Twenty six crystal structures of [Ln<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>M<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(oda)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>] complexes have been reported up to now. Seventeen of them belong to the hexagonal crystal system as described in the Section . Most of them contain Cu ions which forces the hexagonal structure due to its anisotropy. The other nine structures are cubic, namely, [{Mn(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>}{MnGd(oda)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>}<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O , [{Mn(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>}{MnLa(oda)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>}<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O , [{Co(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>}{CoSm(oda)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>}<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O , [{Co(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>}{CoDy(oda)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>}<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O , and [{Mg(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>}{MgLn(oda)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>}<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (Ln<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>La, Nd, Eu, Gd, Tb) . The nine structures presented in this work duplicate the number of members in this group. The bivalent ions which have been crystallized in the cubic system, regardless the Ln ion are Mn, Co, Mg, and Ca. The four ions appear as symmetric hexaaquocations in a cavity which varies from 6.5313(8)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å in [{Mg(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>}{MgLa(oda)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>}<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (the larger lanthanide ion)  to 6.5849(1)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å in <ce:bold>9</ce:bold> ([{Ca(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>}{CaLu(oda)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>}<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O, with the smaller lanthanide ion). This suggests that only those ions with the adequate size can fit in the hole. A search with the Cambridge Structure Database (CSD version 5.33) , reveals that mean distance M(II)–O for these hexaaquocations included in metal–organic frameworks is over 2.6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, Ca–O 2.906<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, Mn–O 2.676<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, and Mg–O 2.614<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. [Co(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> seems to be smaller in average, with Co–O distance 2.605<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. Hexagonal and cubic structures are reported for the Co(II) compounds . [Zn(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> with Zn–O average distance of 2.590<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å seems to be too small to fix the cavity of the anionic network, and only hexagonal structures are found .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Twenty six crystal structures of [Ln2M3(oda)6] complexes have been reported up to now. Seventeen of them belong to the hexagonal crystal system as described in the Section . Most of them contain Cu ions which forces the hexagonal structure due to its anisotropy. The other nine structures are cubic, namely, [{Mn(H2O)6}{MnGd(oda)3}2]·6H2O , [{Mn(H2O)6}{MnLa(oda)3}2]·6H2O , [{Co(H2O)6}{CoSm(oda)3}2]·3H2O , [{Co(H2O)6}{CoDy(oda)3}2]·6H2O , and [{Mg(H2O)6}{MgLn(oda)3}2]·6H2O (Ln=La, Nd, Eu, Gd, Tb) . The nine structures presented in this work duplicate the number of members in this group. The bivalent ions which have been crystallized in the cubic system, regardless the Ln ion are Mn, Co, Mg, and Ca. The four ions appear as symmetric hexaaquocations in a cavity which varies from 6.5313(8)Å in [{Mg(H2O)6}{MgLa(oda)3}2]·6H2O (the larger lanthanide ion)  to 6.5849(1)Å in 9 ([{Ca(H2O)6}{CaLu(oda)3}2]·3H2O, with the smaller lanthanide ion). This suggests that only those ions with the adequate size can fit in the hole. A search with the Cambridge Structure Database (CSD version 5.33) , reveals that mean distance M(II)–O for these hexaaquocations included in metal–organic frameworks is over 2.6Å, Ca–O 2.906Å, Mn–O 2.676Å, and Mg–O 2.614Å. [Co(H2O)6]2+ seems to be smaller in average, with Co–O distance 2.605Å. Hexagonal and cubic structures are reported for the Co(II) compounds . [Zn(H2O)6]2+ with Zn–O average distance of 2.590Å seems to be too small to fix the cavity of the anionic network, and only hexagonal structures are found .

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0165" view="all">Compounds <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>6</ce:bold> exhibit the typical magnetic behavior of isolated Ln(III) ions with deviations from the Curie law mainly owing to the split of the ground term due to the crystal or ligand field for the case of Yb(III). For the case of Eu(III) the paramagnetic behavior is due to the magnetic properties of the exited terms. This behavior is in agreement with the Ln(III) ions being very far from each other in these structures, thus implying exceedingly weak (if any) magnetic interaction . This seems to be a common feature for [Ln<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>M<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(oda)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>] complexes with cubic structures.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Compounds 2 and 6 exhibit the typical magnetic behavior of isolated Ln(III) ions with deviations from the Curie law mainly owing to the split of the ground term due to the crystal or ligand field for the case of Yb(III). For the case of Eu(III) the paramagnetic behavior is due to the magnetic properties of the exited terms. This behavior is in agreement with the Ln(III) ions being very far from each other in these structures, thus implying exceedingly weak (if any) magnetic interaction . This seems to be a common feature for [Ln2M3(oda)6] complexes with cubic structures.
